meta_data.title: Let’s Talk! A Conversation on Universalism and Reason

medical truth or psychological truth or mathematical truth, like if it's the truth, God agrees with it.
No matter who it is, who, which human states it. Um, and so obviously in my world as a psychologist,
one of my areas, um, I don't know how many thousands of times over the years I've said,
if Sigmund Freud says something that's true, the fact that he's Sigmund Freud doesn't make it
untrue. Like the fact that he's a, you know, probably a multi-level addict who ran no experiments,
but made all types of experimental conclusions, like he's a terrible person to, to trust in for
almost anything. But if he says two plus two is four, it's still four, even though Freud's the one
who said it. Um, if Freud says a lie, it's a, if our falsehood, it's a falsehood. If he says a
truth, it's a truth. And if Freud came up with something that no one before him had come up with,
meaning, you know, and I don't know that he did, but if he said something that it was a true
statement that is true, it's still true because all truth is God's truth. God is the ultimate source
of all truth. Um, and so that's true. That's true about psychology and it's true about reason and
rationality. And if we reach a true conclusion, then it's still true. No, really, no matter how
we got there, that's one of the weird things is even if we got there the wrong way, if we still
come to the right answer, it's still the right answer. Um, which is a funky way that God created
the universe is that the truth gets to be the truth no matter what we think about it, whether
we know it, like it, believe it, or agree with it, it's still the truth. Um, and if it is the truth,
then it is the truth, whether it's found in scripture or whether it's uncovered through
empirical evidence or whether it's uncovered from rationality, um, or whatever. So Ren, where would
you go with that? Yeah, I think we may not have enough time to, like you're saying, to unpack all
of it, but I think that's a valuable conversation. Just, I mean, for our whole goal for this podcast,
one, but, um, also just for Christians to understand it's, yeah, you do have to, to navigate
it with discernment because we do believe that scripture is the foundation where we go back to,
but that doesn't mean that God doesn't use and, and we, we don't believe that, you know, scripture is
incomplete in revelate, you know, that type of conversation of scripture somehow incomplete in
what God's provided for us. But we also believe that God has used, um, you know, humans in his work
to provide good gifts to each other, to help each other in our spiritual walk. And like,
I think a lot of that is part of this conversation of why is it the conversation that we,
that prompted this was why is it okay to use reason, um, when tackling a lot of these hard things
and not just say, well, if scripture doesn't blatantly say something,
then we're not going to dig into it any further. Um, and I think that's a valuable question for
Christians to answer because a lot of what we do on this podcast is using scripture as our foundation
for truth, but also digging into reason and logic and psychology. And we don't believe that those
things are somehow opposed to each other, but then it's another avenue that God has given us
to a discover the truth that he's revealed, but also to encourage each other in walking
that path of like discovering truth. So psychology, you know, Chris being an expert in psychology,
and that doesn't mean that he is a psychologist. And then over here, he believes in, you know,
the truth of scripture. Yeah. I don't have multiple personalities when it comes to that.
Right. But I think this is a important thing for Christians to wrestle with. Can we use our minds?
Does God even biblically, and this is the part we may want to dig into later, but biblically,
does God even encourage us to use our minds and logic and reason when it comes to discovering
truth about him and reading scripture and, uh, engaging with our world? That's great. I don't
know if that's a good summary, but yeah, that is, I think we, I think we've said many times that,
you know, if, if the Bible is infallible as a source of truth, but if, so if our understanding
of scripture seems to come in conflict with our understanding of another source of information,
like scientific knowledge or, or reason, then that just means that our understanding of at
least one of them is wrong. It doesn't mean scripture is wrong, but our understanding of
scripture can be wrong. And it could mean our reason is wrong. It could mean our scientific
understanding is wrong. Our intuition is wrong. Um, scripture is infallible. It won't be wrong,
but our understanding of it certainly can be because we're fallible, even though it isn't.
And so we looked at it for an infallible source, knowing that we're, we are fallible receptors.
And so yeah, we, we wrestle through them when they do seem to conflict, that tells us there's a problem.
Um, and we have to continue to dig until truth aligns. And that's what we look for.
So great stuff. Good conversation. Thanks guys.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of reconstructed faith. If you enjoyed what you
heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed,
shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed faith is a resource of South
Spring Baptist church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
